QMRF.author: European Chemicals Bureau
QMRF.contact: European Chemicals Bureau, IHCP, Joint Research Centre, European Commission
QMRF.name: (Q)SAR Model Reporting Format

QSAR_identifier.name: QSAR identifier
QSAR_identifier.QSAR_title: <html> <head> </head> <body> Mutagenic activity in Salmonella typhimurium TA100; αβ-unsaturated aliphatic aldehydes. </body></html>

QSAR_General_information.name: General information

model_date.name: Date of model development and/or publication

references.name: Reference(s) to main scientific papers and/or software package

info_availability.name: Availability of information about the model

QSAR_General_information.info_availability: <html> <head> </head> <body> The model is non-proprietary; the training and test sets are available </body></html>

related_models.name: Availability of another QMRF for exactly the same model

QSAR_Endpoint.name: Defining the endpoint ЎV OECD Principle 1
QSAR_Endpoint.endpoint_protocol: <html> <head> </head> <body> Training set data from literature (different laboratories); mostly using pre-incubation at 37° without exogenous metabolic activation. Test set data from one laboratory using pre-incubation at 37° without exogenous metabolic activation. </body></html>
QSAR_Endpoint.endpoint_data_quality: <html> <head> </head> <body> Literature sources have been critically reviewed by the authors of the model. </body></html>

QSAR_Algorithm.name: Defining the algorithm ЎV OECD Principle 2

algorithm_explicit.name: Explicit algorithm
algorithm_explicit.equation: <html> <head> </head> <body> w = 0.387 MR – 3.12 logP + 3.23 LUMO w(mean,Class1) = 9.689 N1 = 3 (non-mutagens) w(mean,Class2) = 6.373 N2 = 17 (mutagens) Threshold = 8.032 </body></html>

QSAR_Algorithm.algorithm_comments: <html> <head> </head> <body> The algorithm was originally derived through Linear Discriminant Analysis. The present form is mathematically equivalent to the original one, and has been generated through Canonical Discriminant Analysis for the sake of simplicity and ease of implementation.W(mean, Class) is the average value for each of the two classes in the training set. When calculated for an individual chemical, W indicates to which class the chemical should be assigned, based on the Threshold (given above) that separates the two classes. </body></html>
QSAR_Algorithm.descriptors_selection: <html> <head> </head> <body> Descriptors initially screened: MR, logP, LUMO, energy of the Highest Occupied Molecular Orbital (HOMO), partial charge on the carbonilic carbon; partial charge on the β carbon. The descriptors were selected by testing different combinations based on mechanistic hypotheses, together with the use of Stepwise Linear Discriminant Analysis </body></html>
QSAR_Algorithm.descriptors_generation: <html> <head> </head> <body> MR: from the Daylight software freely available on-line in the period 2003 – 2005 (values transformed by multiplying X 10); logP: from the Daylight software freely available on-line in the period 2003 – 2005; LUMO, HOMO, and partial charges were generated with the PM3 Hamiltonian in MOPAC 6.0. </body></html>

descriptors_generation_software.name: Software name and version for descriptor generation

QSAR_Algorithm.descriptors_chemicals_ratio: <html> <head> </head> <body> number of descriptors to number of chemicals from the training set =3 (6 originally screened) to 20 </body></html>

QSAR_Applicability_domain.name: Defining the applicability domain ЎV OECD Principle 3

app_domain_description.name: Description of the applicability domain of the model

QSAR_Applicability_domain.app_domain_description: <html> <head> </head> <body> The applicability domain of the model is defined in terms of: a) structures to which it applies; b) range of values of the descriptors in the model. In the comparison of the test to the training set, mathematical chemical structural similarity is also applied. </body></html>

app_domain_method.name: Method used to assess the applicability domain

QSAR_Applicability_domain.app_domain_method: <html> <head> </head> <body> Structures were checked by human experts. Ranges of descriptors values were calculated. Mathematical chemical similarity between test and training set was assessed as follows. The training and test sets are combined, and the overall Tanimoto similarity matrix is calculated with the computer software Leadscope. An Euclidian distance matrix is calculated from the similarity matrix and then subjected to Principal Component Analysis. Finally, the ranges of PC scores for the training and test sets are compared. </body></html>

app_domain_software.name: Software name and version for applicability domain assessment

QSAR_Applicability_domain.applicability_limits: <html> <head> </head> <body> The models applies to αβ -unsaturated aldehydes with both aliphatic and aromatic substituents. Chemicals with different functional groups, such as carboxylates, should be excluded, as well as aldehydes with the unsaturated bond within a ring structure, since they may have a different type of reactivity.Ranges of descriptors for the training set:MR (10xDaylight): 16.55 51.71logP: -0.01 2.95LUMO: -1.159 -0.101 </body></html>

QSAR_Robustness.name: Defining goodness-of-fit and robustness - OECD Principle 4

training_set_data.name: Available information for the training set

QSAR_Robustness.training_set_data: The following information for the training set is reported as supporting information: a) Chemical names (common names); b) CAS numbers; c) SMILES; d) Structural formula

training_set_descriptors.name: Data for each descriptor variable for the training set

QSAR_Robustness.training_set_descriptors: The descriptor values of the training set are available and are attached as supporting information.

dependent_var_availability.name: Data for the dependent variable for the training set

QSAR_Robustness.dependent_var_availability: The dependent variable values of the training set are available and attached as supporting information

other_info.name: Other information about the training set:

QSAR_Robustness.other_info: <html> <head> </head> <body> Number of compounds in the training set = 20 (Negatives = 3; Positives = 17). </body></html>

loo.name: Robustness : Statistics obtained by leave-one-out cross-validation

lmo.name: Robustness : Statistics obtained by leave-many-out cross-validation

QSAR_Robustness.lmo: <html> <head> </head> <body> Since the training set includes only 3 negatives, no meaningful LMO cross-validation is possible. </body></html>

other_statistics.name: Robustness : Statistics obtained by other methods

QSAR_Predictivity.name: Defining predictivity - OECD Principle 4

validation_set_availability.name: Availability of the external validation set

QSAR_Predictivity.validation_set_availability: An external validation set is available and appended to the current QMRF as supporting information

validation_set_data.name: Available information for the external validation set

QSAR_Predictivity.validation_set_data: he following information for the external validation set is reported as supporting information: a) Chemical names (common names); b) CAS numbers; c) SMILES; d) Structural formula.

validation_set_descriptors.name: Data for each descriptor variable for the external validation set

QSAR_Predictivity.validation_set_descriptors: The descriptor values of the external validation set are available and are attached as supporting information.

validation_dependent_var_availability.name: Data for the dependent variable for the external validation set

QSAR_Predictivity.validation_dependent_var_availability: The dependent variable values of the external validation set are available and attached as supporting information.

validation_other_info.name: Other information about the external validation set

QSAR_Predictivity.validation_other_info: <html> <head> </head> <body> External validation set with 5 compounds appended. </body></html>
QSAR_Predictivity.experimental_design: <html> <head> </head> <body> Whereas the training set chemicals were retrieved from literature, the test set was generated by prospective experimental testing after modelling. The applicability domain was taken into account by considering the factors of chemical structure, range of descriptors values, chemical similarity.Chemicals with different functional groups, such as carboxylates, were excluded, as well as aldehydes with the unsaturated bond within a ring structure, since they may have a different type of reactivity.Ranges of descriptors for the test set:MR (10xDaylight): 25.80 69.10logP: 0.59 3.49LUMO: -0.827 0.074Range of chemical similarity indices (PCs): Training set (N=20) Test set (N=5) Minimum Maximum Minimum Maximum Factor1 -0.976 1.524 -0.866 1.753 Factor2 -1.707 1.853 0.005 2.764 Factor3 -2.616 1.238 -2.508 1.717 </body></html>

validation_predictivity.name: Predictivity ЎV Statistics obtained by external validation

validation_assessment.name: Predictivity ЎV Assessment of the external validation set

QSAR_Predictivity.validation_assessment: <html> <head> </head> <body> The test set is representative of the applicability domain; no further chemicals to test experimentally were available from commercial catalogues. </body></html>

validation_comments.name: Comments on the external validation of the model

QSAR_Interpretation.name: Providing a mechanistic interpretation ЎV OECD Principle 5
QSAR_Interpretation.mechanistic_basis: <html> <head> </head> <body> High electrophilicity, low steric hindrance and high lipophilicity favor the activity. This result is concordant with the scientific evidence on mechanism of action of these chemicals, which react as direct electrophiles to form adducts with DNA (and proteins). </body></html>

mechanistic_basis_comments.name: A priori or a posteriori mechanistic interpretatio

QSAR_Interpretation.mechanistic_basis_comments: <html> <head> </head> <body> The descriptors to be screened were selected based on the knowledge on the mechanisms of action. The descriptors actually accepted in the model confirm the a priori hypotheses </body></html>

mechanistic_basis_info.name: Other information about the mechanistic interpretation

QSAR_Interpretation.mechanistic_basis_info:
<html> <head>
</head> <body> references supporting the mechanistic basis: Woo YT, Lai DY, McLain JL, Ko Manibusan M, Dellarco V. Use of mechanism-based structure-activity relationships analysis in carcinogenic potential ranking for drinking water disinfection by-products. Environ.Health Perspect. 2002; 110: 75-87. Feron VJ, Til HP, de Vrijer F, Woutersen RA, Cassee FR, van Bladeren PJ. Aldehydes: occurrence, carcinogenic potential, mechanism of action and risk assessment. Mutat.Res. 1991; 259: 363-385. Eder E, Deininger C. Mutagenicity of 2-Alkylpropenals in Salmonella typhimurium strain TA 100: structural influences. Environ.Mol.Mutagen. 2001; 37: 324-328. Yang I-Y, Johnson F, Grollman AP, Moriya M. Genotoxic mechanism for the major acrolein-derived deoxyguanosine adduct in human cells. Chem.Res.Toxicol. 2002; 15: 160-164. </body> </html>

software.name: Daylight software, freely available on-line in the period 2003 ЎV 2005
MOPAC 6.0 Quantum Chemistry Program Exchange, Bloomington
Leadscope v 2.4 for the Tanimoto chemical similarity index.

descriptor.description: logarithm of the partition coefficient between octanol and water
descriptor.name: logP

descriptor.description: energy of the Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbital
descriptor.name: LUMO

publication.title: R. Benigni, L. Passerini, and A. Rodomonte (2003) Structure-activity relationships for the mutagenicity and carcinogenicity of simple and αβ-unsaturated aldehydes. Environ.Mol.Mutag., 42: 136-143.

R. Benigni, L. Conti, R. Crebelli, A. Rodomonte, and M. R. VariЎ¦ (2005) Simple and αβ unsaturated aldehydes: correct prediction of genotoxic activity through structure-activity relationship models. Environ.Mol.Mutagenesis, 46: 268-280.
